bestBHT.bht: In this heartfelt expression of praise, we are reminded to give all glory to God, our loving Father. The doxology serves as a reminder of His abundant grace and provision, ascribing to Him the endlessness of glory. It emphasizes that our riches and strength do not come from ourselves, but from Him. As we contemplate the completion of His work and His gracious recompense, we are called to humbly acknowledge that all goodness flows from His mercy and favor.

Henry Alford: The contemplation both of the Christian reward, of which he has been speaking, and of the glorious completion of all God’s dealings at the great day,—and the close of his Epistle,—suggests this ascription of praise.
But—however rich you may be in good works, however strong I may be by Christ to bear all things,—not to us, but to our God and Father be the glory.
On the expression rendered for ever and ever, see note, Eph. iii. 21.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Not to us, but to Him be 'the glory'.
The glory" of your gift, and of His gracious recompense to you.
Albert Barnes: Now unto God and our Father...
It was common for Paul to address such an ascription of praise to God, at the close of his epistles.
John Calvin: It became him to reckon himself indebted to them in such a manner as to acknowledge, that this aid had been afforded to them by the mercy of God.
The liberality which the Philippians had exercised towards St. Paul.
The assistance which the Philippians had afforded him.
Philip Schaff: To our God . . . is the glory," - It is His to bestow on those who have done here what is well-pleasing in His sight.
The expression is very strong, and implies the endlessness of the glory which belongs, and should be ascribed, unto God." - The endlessness of the glory belongs and should be ascribed to God.

It might therefore be well to make the verse a direct statement: ‘To our God . . . is the glory,’ etc." - It might be well to make the verse a direct statement to emphasize the glory that belongs to God.
Archibald T. Robertson: The glory (η δοξα). "The doxology flows out of the joy of the whole epistle" (Bengel).
John Gill: To God, who is our Father in Christ, [be] glory for ever and ever, Amen; for all the grace he gives now, and for all the glory and happiness expected hereafter.
For the supply of every want both temporal and spiritual; seeing every good gift comes from him, and is to be ascribed to his free grace and favour, and not to any deserts of men.
And particularly he may mean for what they had sent him, and he had received from them.

bhtAttempts.bht: The doxology in Philippians 4:20 is a reflective and heartfelt expression of praise and thanksgiving to God. Through this ascription of glory, Paul reminds the Philippians that the ultimate source of their riches, strength, and good works lies not in themselves, but in their God and Father. The verse emphasizes the endlessness of the glory that belongs to God, as it flows out of the joy and completion of all His dealings. By acknowledging that all grace, assistance, and provisions come from Him, Paul highlights the undeserved nature of these gifts. Ultimately, the doxology serves as a reminder to the Philippians that any glory they receive should be attributed solely to God and not to themselves.

The doxology in Philippians 4:20 praises and glorifies God for His abundant grace and provisions. It serves as a reminder that our riches and strength come not from ourselves, but from our God and Father. This expression of thanksgiving reflects the joy and completion of God's dealings with us. By acknowledging that all good gifts come from Him, Paul emphasizes the undeserved nature of His favor. The verse emphasizes the endlessness of the glory that belongs to God, and highlights the importance of attributing all glory to Him alone.

The doxology in this passage directs our attention to the ultimate source of our riches and strength: our God and Father. It is a reflection of gratitude for His abundant grace and provision. As we contemplate the completion of God's work and the reward that awaits us, we are reminded to ascribe all glory to Him alone. This expression of praise signifies the endlessness of His glory and the undeserved nature of His gifts. Through this doxology, we are called to humbly acknowledge that all goodness comes from Him.

In this heartfelt expression of praise, we are reminded to give all glory to God, our loving Father. The doxology serves as a reminder of His abundant grace and provision, ascribing to Him the endlessness of glory. It emphasizes that our riches and strength do not come from ourselves, but from Him. As we contemplate the completion of His work and His gracious recompense, we are called to humbly acknowledge that all goodness flows from His mercy and favor.

The doxology in this passage calls us to direct our praise and glory to God, our loving Father. It serves as a reminder that our riches and strength come not from our own efforts, but from Him. As we reflect on His abundant grace and provision, we are prompted to acknowledge the endlessness of His glory and the undeserved nature of His gifts. This expression of gratitude highlights that all good things, both temporal and spiritual, come from Him and should be attributed to His grace and favor.
